body: removed "global request section".  refactored into common node metrics
Thanks for the patch. LGTM. Just a minor comment.

There wasn't exactly a scientific approach taken to get to this value, 1 GB just seemed like a safe size as a default value. It's large enough to cover a relatively large window of time yet small enough to mitigate concerns about disk exhaustion. 

GC logs have been seen to grow at roughly 50MB at day within a moderately utilized production cluster. At this rate 1GB seems a bit much but during times of duress when the jvm is actively performing GC the rate may rise. 

I'm definitely open to any suggestion anyone may have though.
LGTM, thanks for your patience. :)
Merged to trunk and 0.10.0 branches.
LGTM, thanks. Merging to trunk.
Thanks for the PR. A couple of comments (one from me and one from Jason) and the rest looks good.

thanks for the review @ijuma updated, please check.thanks.

Thanks for the PR @satendrakumar06. It is certainly better to use `if/else` for such cases.

I left a few comments. Can you please review the whole PR and make sure it doesn't have unrelated changes and that the changes follow Kafka's code conventions? Once you do that, there will be less noise and I can do a better review.

Thanks for the PR @rekhajoshm. It's mostly fine although I still see many examples where `size` was changed to `length` for arrays. We don't have a rule or guideline that arrays should use `length` instead of `size` in Kafka, so it would be better to remove those changes.

Also, can you please update the PR title to follow our convention as described here https://cwiki.apache.org/confluence/display/KAFKA/Contributing+Code+Changes? Something like:

> KAFKA-3765; Kafka Code style corrections

Finally, the PR description doesn't have to repeat the PR title and please update it so that it doesn't include "using slength where optimum instead of size".
@arunmahadevan, thanks for the explanation. Can you update the PR description to be accurate then? The PR description becomes the commit message in the merged commit, so its contents are important.

done, please check.thanks @ijuma 
Where it fits, length over size in scala, as size needs additional implicit conversion to SeqLike, length can provide significant performance advantage.However as you called out, scala doc does not have a clear guideline on that, hence updated as per your review comment.thanks.
@ijuma Thanks for quick review.  Sorry for inconvenience. Definitely, I will do these changes and I should  follow Kafka's code conventions.

Thanks for the PR, LGTM. Merging to trunk.

With regards to the `Array.size`, note that the implicit conversions rely on value classes (i.e. they extend from `AnyVal`), so there should be no object creation as of Scala 2.10 (it was different in Scala 2.9.x).

@ijuma Is any way to verify Kafka's code conventions before creating pull request ?
Like:
`./gradlew checkstyleMain checkstyleTest`
It is only for java.

ok thanks @ijuma

@guozhangwang 

Changes made per comments.
I don't think the changes from this PR are responsible for the build failure.

I'm not sure it is safe to assume jps will be available. I think its packaged as a jdk tool and some installations that only have JRE won't have the tool (at least that's how things are organized in the Ubuntu OpenJDK packages and I assume that falls out directly from upstream JRE/JDK distinctions).
Review by @guozhangwang.

Agreed. Thanks for the feedback. 

In Linux, the `ps` command seems to truncate the result to 4096 characters (it expands the full path of all the libraries in the classpath.). So, `ps ax | grep -i 'kafka\.Kafka'` returns nothing.
Can this be merged to `0.10` to fix current online documentation?
Again, I don't think the pushed changes are responsible for the failure.  Tests for the streams project run fine locally, not sure what the error is from.

Yes, we've run into this with system tests. I think generally the solution was to reduce `CLASSPATH` length by making sure `*` is used properly without expansion to minimize the number of `CLASSPATH` entries (or setup the full `CLASSPATH` and export it), although I think writing a pid file is a much more reliable solution.
@ijuma Please can you take a look? thank you.
LGTM
@ijuma This looks good to me, though I wonder why `def` instead of `lazy val`?
@ijuma Please review it. Let me know in any changes required.
@gfodor can you add JIRA title to your PR,  like "KAFKA-3770: KStream job should be able to specify linger.ms"

@ewencp lazy val is good when something is used more than once as there is some cost (double-checked locking with an additional field to capture whether initialisation has taken place). Since `numAcks` is used only once, a plain `def` (i.e. a method) seemed like the right option.
@ijuma Thank you for the review. I have made all except one of the changes you suggested. Have left a comment for the remaining one.
LGTM. Please feel free to merge.
LGTM
@ewencp Happy to re visit this and update it. I will look it over and try to trim it down, let me know if there are any specific entries I should remove.
We definitely fixed this before. To be clear, is this is a hotfix just for the 0.9 branch?
@onurkaraman Yes, correct. I think Ismael fixed it for 0.10, but we should at least have it in the 0.9 branch in case we do another release.
@guozhangwang, what do you think? I was able to run the examples and see the metrics per node in a jmx console.
Thanks @aartigupta , @enothereska could you take a look first at this ticket? I have assigned you as the reviewer on the ticket, and please feel free to re-assign to me otherwise.

Hello @gfodor, regarding the second item, could you elaborate a bit about the "various unnecessary work"? Also I do not know how you directly addressed it in your patch.

About the first item, I agree that for some simple topology (i.e. a record takes very few cycles to process) recording the latency for each record could be an overhead, and we could possibly approximate it by recording the total time for a batch and divided by the batch size as "average latency for processing a record". But I am a bit unclear for your use case as you mention it is "a complex streams job", which I assume means on average processing a record would take long time, then in this case, it is abnormal to see this metric recording taking 50% CPU to me.

Thanks @gfodor , LGTM overall. Could you add a test case in `StreamsConfigTest` for validating that underlying clients' specific configs like `ProducerConfig.LINGER_MS_CONFIG` and `ConsumerConfig.AUTO_OFFSET_RESET_CONFIG` are successfully passed via `StreamsConfig`?

Hmm, this is quite interesting..

```
pure virtual method called
terminate called without an active exception
:streams:test FAILED
```

We have seen this failure before, which I believe is due to RocksDB instances not closed in time, and I thought it has been resolved in https://github.com/apache/kafka/pull/1258, since then I have not seen it again.

@bbejeck I have not looked into the patch in details, but could you think of any chance that the changes could affects how we close and dispose any RocksDB objects?
LGTM

Thanks @guozhangwang !

For the changes to Fetcher.java, this was being called repeatedly but was concatenating strings, doing string replace, and constructing that hashmap each time metrics were recorded. (About 7% of CPU time was spent on the string.replace!)

For 'complex', what I am referring to here is a job with a lot of tasks processing a lot of partitions. Our job runs against about 18 topics, most of which have 16 partitions and two which have 128. In the profiling I did, a vast majority of the CPU time was spent in the Sensor.record() call, both for the metrics of the run loop around poll + process time, and the latency measuring when reading/writing from the state stores. The job in question does very little processing for most records, with a very small % of records doing significant work.
@hachikuji, can you please close this PR since it's been merged? (auto-close only works when merging to trunk).

Well that's certainly possible, but the tests run fine locally.  I didn't think the changes would have caused the failures because the net effect is mostly the same as the original PR, I just took a different approach.  I'll update and re-run the tests.  

EDIT: I just updated/rebased and all the streams tests pass locally.  I'm running on Mac OS X   10.10.5.  I'll continue to look and see if I can find something.
looking forward to your review @ijuma thanks.
LGTM, merged to trunk.

As for reducing the sensor call for recording `poll` latency, usually `consumer.poll` should only be called infrequently when there are not enough data in the buffer, so I would be surprised if `sensors.pollTimeSensor.record(endPoll - startPoll);` is called very frequently, could you verify if that is the case? If yes, maybe you can consider tuning buffer size and consumer max poll records to reduce the polling frequency.

As for recording "process" latency, a few optimizations that I can think of if we want to maintain its semantics (i.e. processing latency per record):
1. Only call "task.process()" if the buffer size is not zero, meaning that `process` will take effect.
2. Accumulate process time (maybe also "poll") inside the run loop as well as the number of times they are called, and take the average per every X `runLoop` to call `record`.

@bbejeck I re-ran the unit test with your patch and it passed locally as well, so I think this may be due to some corner cases still unresolved from #1258 , will investigate further separately by enhancing some logging information.
Thanks @rajinisivaram, LGTM.
It may make sense to do a separate PR for the `Fetcher` changes including my suggestions. That's a clear improvement with no semantic changes.
Review by @gwenshap or @junrao.
@edoardocomar, sorry for the delay. I investigated the issue and I think #1455 should fix it (I briefly tested your PR with it).
@lindong28 Thank you for your feedback. I responded to your comments inline.

@guozhangwang the profiler I was using didn't capture the call stacks in a way that I could tell, since those are both in the same routine, but I'm guessing you are probably right assuming that the major contributor was the measurement of calls to process(). The patch here I believe does approach (2) to solve the problem, but by doing so makes it so it becomes an average metric and the max/min would effectively become the "max average and min average time per iteration" which is different than what it is now, which is the max or min of a specific process() call. We could probably capture the max/min as well as the average, and record these metrics separately from the runLoop(), but I'd imagine that'd have some impact on the structure of the code b/c the sensors are generally responsible for the max/min/avg calc.

I'd also like to know your thoughts on the latency metrics, which I didn't address in this patch. In my measurements ~80-90% of the time of the call stack for accessing the state stores was writing the latency metrics.

thanks @ijuma does this mean that I should be able to get rid of 
 OffsetCommitRequiredAcksProp=1 ?
Yes.

@rajinisivaram The eager removal of unknown topics seems questionable to me. It looks like we just end up complicating other parts of the code to add the removed topics back into the `Metadata` instance. I'm wondering if this actually solves the problem of unknown topic log spam. In particular, it seems like we would still log the unknown topic on each metadata fetch in `KafkaProducer.waitOnMetadata`.
@junrao I addressed your previous comments. Would you take another look?

Hi @dguy , thanks for the patch. Overall looks good. Here is one general comment:

We should not require serdes in `KStream.map()` as it is supposed to be non-stateful operators and hence users are not expected to have any materialization JUST FOR this operator. Plus, some other operators like `selectKey` would also need similar handing if we do this direction.

As about join operations, since the join operators already requires the serdes which would be just reused for the repartition topic, we do not need to require it before hand in `map`, `selectKeys`, etc. Similar situation for `reduce`, which already requires the serdes for original key and value.

Hence the only problem is for `aggregate`, where the original value serde is not provided. After thinking about it for a bit more, I'm now more towards doing KAFKA-3576 for aggregations as well, i.e. introduce a `KGroupedStream` which can be generated from `KStream.groupBy` (which can then require serdes). In addition, `KStream.groupBy` may also take a `Windows` spec (we can overload the function with and without this parameter) so that later aggregations do not need to specify it anymore.
@vahidhashemian This mostly looks good, but left a few minor comments.

A few more suggestions:
1. As in `KGroupedTable KTable.groupBy(..)`, the repartitioning does not happen at the `groupBy` operator, but we carry the serde information as well as the select-key mapper along with the `KGroupedTable`, which can only call aggregations; then the repartitioning is done when `aggregate / reduce / etc` is really called. We can do the same for `KStream`.
2. A few differences of the `KGroupedStream` though, is that besides the serde and key-select mapper information, we can also allow users to specify the Windows spec so that the `KGroupedStream` conceptually captures a stream grouped by key and as well as windows (this is from user interfacing point of view only, no correctness issues at all), then its aggregation function do not need to provide any Windowing specs any more.
3. Also for `KGroupedStream.reduce`, we do not need to require users provide any more serdes, as they should already be provided in the previous `groupBy`.
4. As for joins, we are going to still let users do the pattern of `stream1.selectKey().join(stream2, serdes..)` or `stream1.map().join(stream2, serdes..)`, but auto-creating the repartition topic inside the `join` operator; note that again since the serdes are passed in the later join operator, we do not need to enforce users to provide them in previous `selectKey` or `map` operator.

Let me know if you have more questions.
@hachikuji Thank you for the recent feedback. I updated the PR based on your suggestion.

Yeah the min / max metrics will be affected, we'd best keep their semantics for monitoring purposes. Give me some time and let's see if there is a better approach.

About the state store latency metrics: are you using RocksDB or just in-memory stores? Again I'm quite surprised to see that most of the time is spent in metrics recording, unless it is pure in-memory. In that case I'm thinking maybe it makes more sense to only record metrics for persistent stores.

BTW just clarifying are you using the JMX reporter or any other reporters?

I'm using the local JMX reporter. Also the stores involved were RocksDB
stores which were recording state for every incoming message (a few
thousand tps.)

@vahidhashemian Thanks for the iterations. LGTM.

@edoardocomar With producer-property can we override multiple producer configurations. Because When I am trying like below
bin/kafka-console-producer.sh --broker-list <server:port> --topic mytopic --producer-property security.protocol=SASL_PLAINTEXT fetch.min.bytes=2

only security.protocol is getting overriding, where as fetch .min.bytes is still showing as default value 1.

Because when arguments are parsed and used options.valuesOf(producerPropertyOpt) is returning only one value because of space fetch.min.bytes is not considered here.

  val extraProducerProps = CommandLineUtils.parseKeyValueArgs(options.valuesOf(producerPropertyOpt))

Is that it works for only one parameter or I am doing something not correctly? Can you please let me know your inputs.
@guozhangwang, can you please update the `Common build options` section of the `Readme`? The code changes look good.
cc @guozhangwang

0.10.0.0 has been released, should we revisit this? I also wonder if we need to be a bit more careful removing deprecated features in 0.10.1.0 since this is probably a bit shorter of a timeframe than people would normally expect for deprecation + removal. Normally I would expect removal of deprecated features to happen on major releases, but the quick succession from 0.9 to 0.10 kinda broke that approach for anything deprecated in 0.9.

Regardless of the decision, it might be nice to start marking these deprecation bugs in JIRA with the fix version as soon as they are filed based on the major version bump, and mark them as blockers by default so they can easily be included in a release and don't just get lost.

@guozhangwang
 made changes per review comments.  Looks like my rebase/squash was unsuccessful let me know if you want me to close this PR and issue another one.
@coughman I think @hachikuji's comment about duplicates still holds -- I see request-rate, request-size-avg, request-size-max, etc multiple times.

@ewencp  AFAIK we will be removing the deprecated features in next major release(0.11.0.0). If all agree then, I will update the fix version accordingly.

cc @ijuma

It doesn't seem safe to add the `--old-consumer` option and change the default in one release. How can people migrate their scripts if there isn't a window during which both `--old-consumer` and `--new-consumer` options work? Seems like it could catch people unawares with a new release where they will have had to provide paths for both cases to support a seamless migration. Something like `ConsumerPerformance` is probably low risk, `ConsumerGroupCommand` seems like it could break things for a lot of people... (Ideally we'd have a way besides release notes to also warn of the switch; something like deprecation but with a slightly different meaning.)
LGTM
LGTM, thanks!
@becketqin It looks like you may have accidentally pulled in unrelated changes?
@ijuma Updated the PR title. Let me know if it makes sense.
@Ishiihara Ping for follow-up -- change LGTM but we'd need a couple of tests (which would then fail and need to be converted if we updated for KAFKA_3734)

@ewencp the proposed patch doesn't remove the `--new-consumer` option. Both `--old-consumer` and `--new-consumer` are supported, with new consumer being the default if neither options are provided. This would probably break the user scripts that uses the current default (old consumer) since the new consumer expects a `bootstrap-server` instead of `zookeeper url`. They would have to either add an extra `--old-consumer` option if they wish to continue with the old consumer or move to the new consumer.

May be we can show a warning when `--old-consumer` option is used and prompt users to migrate. If no option is provided but zookeeper url is present (current default), it would throw the same warning and just exit.
LGTM -- this is really just follow up to fix the previous PR. Thanks!
